_link.title: I can recall and apply cell theory

toLevel2.question: Which of the following is a principle of cell theory?

options.text: All living things are made up of at least one cell
options.explanation: Cell theory states that all living organisms are composed of one or more cells.

options.text: Cells can arise spontaneously from non-living matter
options.explanation: Cell theory states that all cells arise from pre-existing cells, not from non-living matter.

options.text: Only multicellular organisms are considered alive
options.explanation: Cell theory includes all living things, whether unicellular or multicellular.

options.text: Viruses are the basic unit of life on Earth
options.explanation: Cells, not viruses, are the basic unit of life according to cell theory.

toLevel2.question: According to cell theory, what is the basic unit of life?

options.text: The cell
options.explanation: Cell theory states that the cell is the basic structural and functional unit of all living organisms.

options.text: The atom
options.explanation: Atoms are the basic unit of matter, but the cell is the basic unit of life according to cell theory.

options.text: The molecule
options.explanation: Molecules are chemical structures, but the cell is the basic unit of life.

options.text: The organ
options.explanation: Organs are made up of tissues, which are made of cells. The cell is the most basic unit of life.

toLevel2.question: According to cell theory, where do new cells come from?

options.text: From pre-existing cells
options.explanation: Cell theory states that all cells arise from pre-existing cells through cell division.

options.text: From non-living chemical reactions
options.explanation: Cell theory rejects the idea of spontaneous generation; new cells come from pre-existing cells.

options.text: From viruses that infect organisms
options.explanation: Viruses do not produce new cells. New cells arise from the division of pre-existing cells.

options.text: From sunlight and water combining
options.explanation: Cells are not produced from sunlight and water. They arise from pre-existing cells through division.

toLevel2.question: Why are viruses not considered living organisms under cell theory?

options.text: Because they are not made up of cells and cannot reproduce on their own
options.explanation: Viruses lack cellular structure and cannot replicate independently; they require a host cell. Cell theory requires all living things to be made of cells.

options.text: Because they are too small to be observed under any microscope
options.explanation: Viruses can be observed using electron microscopes. Their non-living status is due to lacking cells, not their size.

options.text: Because they contain DNA, which only non-living things have
options.explanation: Both living organisms and some viruses contain DNA. The issue is that viruses are not made of cells.

options.text: Because they can only be found in laboratory environments
options.explanation: Viruses are found everywhere in nature. Their classification is based on lacking cellular structure, not their habitat.

toLevel2.question: How many principles does cell theory have?

options.text: Three
options.explanation: Cell theory has three principles: all living things are made of cells, the cell is the basic unit of life, and all cells arise from pre-existing cells.

options.text: One
options.explanation: Cell theory has three principles, not one.

options.text: Five
options.explanation: Cell theory has three core principles.

options.text: Seven
options.explanation: Cell theory has three core principles.

toLevel2.question: Cell theory states that all cells arise from pre-existing cells.
toLevel2.explanation: This is one of the three principles of cell theory: new cells are produced by the division of existing cells.

options.text: True
False

toLevel2.question: According to cell theory, cells can arise spontaneously from non-living matter.
toLevel2.explanation: Cell theory rejects spontaneous generation. All cells arise from pre-existing cells through cell division.

options.text: True
False

According to cell theory, all cells arise from {{blank:1}} cells through cell {{blank:2}}.
Viruses are not considered {{blank:1}} under cell theory because they are not made of {{blank:2}}.

toLevel3.question: Explain why cell theory is considered a foundational concept in biology.

options.text: It underpins our understanding of the origin, structure, and reproduction of all living things
options.explanation: Cell theory provides the foundation for understanding that all life is cellular, cells are the basic functional units, and life continues through cell division.

options.text: It is only important for studying bacteria and has no relevance to plants or animals at all
options.explanation: Cell theory applies to all living organisms, including plants, animals, fungi, and protists, not just bacteria.

options.text: It was the first scientific theory ever proposed and is kept for historical reasons only
options.explanation: Cell theory remains scientifically valid and foundational, not merely historical. It is actively used in modern biology.

options.text: It only describes how cells look under a microscope and has no broader implications for biology
options.explanation: Cell theory extends beyond microscopy to explain the fundamental nature of life, including its origin and reproduction.

toLevel3.question: How does cell theory explain the relationship between unicellular and multicellular organisms?

options.text: Both are living because they are made of at least one cell, with multicellular organisms having many cells working together
options.explanation: Cell theory states all living things are made of cells. Unicellular organisms consist of one cell, while multicellular organisms have many cells that cooperate for complex functions.

options.text: Only multicellular organisms are truly alive because unicellular organisms are too simple to be considered living
options.explanation: Cell theory includes all organisms made of cells, whether unicellular or multicellular. Both are considered living.

options.text: Unicellular organisms are not covered by cell theory because they are not complex enough to qualify
options.explanation: Cell theory explicitly applies to all living things, including unicellular organisms.

options.text: Cell theory states that unicellular organisms must eventually become multicellular to survive long term
options.explanation: Cell theory does not state that unicellular organisms must become multicellular. Both forms of life are equally valid.

toLevel3.question: Describe how cell theory relates to the process of reproduction.

options.text: All new organisms begin as cells that arise from pre-existing cells through division
options.explanation: Cell theory's third principle states that all cells come from pre-existing cells. This means reproduction at the cellular level involves cell division, whether for growth or creating new organisms.

options.text: Reproduction is not related to cell theory because it is a whole-organism process, not a cellular one
options.explanation: Reproduction fundamentally involves cell division, which is directly addressed by cell theory's principle that all cells arise from pre-existing cells.

options.text: Cell theory states that reproduction only occurs in multicellular organisms, not in unicellular ones
options.explanation: Cell theory applies to all organisms. Unicellular organisms reproduce through cell division just as multicellular organisms do.

options.text: New cells are created from scratch during reproduction without any connection to pre-existing cells at all
options.explanation: Cell theory explicitly states that all cells arise from pre-existing cells, rejecting the idea of cells being created from non-living matter.

toLevel3.question: Why does cell theory classify viruses differently from bacteria?

options.text: Bacteria are cellular organisms while viruses lack cells and cannot reproduce independently
options.explanation: Bacteria are unicellular prokaryotes made of cells, fitting cell theory's definition of living. Viruses lack cells and require host cells to replicate, so they are not considered living.

options.text: Both bacteria and viruses are considered non-living under cell theory because both are microscopic
options.explanation: Bacteria are living organisms composed of cells. Being microscopic does not determine whether something is living or non-living.

options.text: Viruses are considered living and bacteria are considered non-living under cell theory principles
options.explanation: This reverses the classification: bacteria are cellular and living, while viruses lack cells and are not considered living.

options.text: Cell theory does not distinguish between viruses and bacteria because both contain genetic material
options.explanation: Cell theory distinguishes them based on cellular structure: bacteria have cells, viruses do not.

toLevel3.question: How does the principle that 'the cell is the basic unit of life' help us understand the structure of complex organisms?

options.text: It means that even complex multicellular organisms are built from individual cells performing specialised functions
options.explanation: Understanding that cells are the basic unit of life means complex organisms can be understood by studying their component cells, each performing specialised functions.

options.text: It means complex organisms are not made of cells but of organs that function independently of cellular biology
options.explanation: Organs are made of tissues, which are made of cells. The cell remains the fundamental building block of all complex organisms.

options.text: It only applies to simple organisms and has no relevance to understanding complex multicellular organisms
options.explanation: The principle applies to all living things, helping us understand that even the most complex organisms are built from cells.

options.text: It means that complex organisms evolved from a single cell type that never diversified or specialised
options.explanation: Complex organisms have many specialised cell types, all derived from the basic unit of life through differentiation.

toLevel3.question: Explain the significance of the principle that 'all cells arise from pre-existing cells' for understanding the continuity of life.

options.text: It means there is an unbroken chain of cell divisions linking all current life to the earliest cells
options.explanation: This principle establishes that life has been continuous since its origin, with every cell today traceable through an unbroken lineage of cell divisions back to the earliest cells.

options.text: It has no significance for understanding life continuity because cells can also arise spontaneously from chemicals
options.explanation: Cell theory rejects spontaneous generation. The continuity of life depends on cells arising only from pre-existing cells.

options.text: It only applies to the last hundred years of life on Earth and not to the origin of life billions of years ago
options.explanation: This principle applies throughout the history of life, establishing a continuous chain of cell divisions from the first cells to all present life.

options.text: It means that cells cannot divide and all organisms must be created fully formed at once
options.explanation: The principle states the opposite: cells do divide, and all new cells come from existing cells through division.

toLevel3.question: Cell theory applies to all living organisms, whether they are unicellular or multicellular.
toLevel3.explanation: Cell theory states that all living things are made of cells, which applies equally to single-celled organisms like bacteria and multicellular organisms like humans.

options.text: True
False

toLevel3.question: Bacteria are considered {{blank:1}} because they are made of cells, while viruses are not because they lack {{blank:2}} structure.
Cell theory establishes that life is {{blank:1}}, with every cell traceable through an unbroken chain of cell {{blank:2}}.
Complex multicellular organisms are built from individual {{blank:1}} performing {{blank:2}} functions.

toLevel4.question: Apply cell theory to determine whether a prion (an infectious protein) should be classified as living.

options.text: Not living, because prions are not made of cells and do not arise from pre-existing cells
options.explanation: Prions are misfolded proteins without cellular structure. They do not meet any of the three principles of cell theory, so they are not classified as living.

options.text: Living, because prions can replicate by converting other proteins to their misfolded form
options.explanation: While prions can cause other proteins to misfold, they are not cells and do not reproduce through cell division, so they are not living under cell theory.

options.text: Living, because prions contain amino acids, which are found in all living organisms
options.explanation: Containing amino acids does not make something alive. Cell theory requires organisms to be made of cells.

options.text: This question cannot be answered because cell theory does not apply to proteins at all
options.explanation: Cell theory can be applied to determine that prions are not living because they lack cellular structure.

toLevel4.question: A scientist discovers a structure that grows, responds to stimuli, but is not made of cells. Apply cell theory to classify this structure.

options.text: Not living, because cell theory requires all living things to be made of at least one cell
options.explanation: Despite showing some life-like properties, the structure is not made of cells and therefore does not meet the requirements of cell theory for classification as living.

options.text: Living, because growth and response to stimuli are sufficient to classify something as alive
options.explanation: Cell theory requires cellular structure. Some non-living things (like crystals or fire) can grow or respond to stimuli but are not alive.

options.text: Living, because cell theory does not require organisms to be made of cells to be classified as alive
options.explanation: Cell theory explicitly requires all living things to be composed of one or more cells.

options.text: The classification depends entirely on whether the structure has DNA, not on whether it has cells
options.explanation: Cell theory classifies living things based on cellular structure, not solely on the presence of DNA.

toLevel4.question: How does cell theory apply to the process of wound healing in multicellular organisms?

options.text: Wound healing involves cell division, where new cells arise from pre-existing cells to replace damaged tissue
options.explanation: Cell theory's principle that all cells arise from pre-existing cells explains wound healing: damaged cells are replaced by new cells produced through division of existing cells.

options.text: Wound healing occurs independently of cell theory because damaged tissue regenerates from non-cellular materials
options.explanation: Wound healing relies on cell division, directly demonstrating cell theory's principle that new cells come from pre-existing cells.

options.text: Cell theory states that damaged cells cannot be replaced, so wound healing contradicts cell theory
options.explanation: Cell theory supports wound healing: new cells arise from division of pre-existing cells to replace damaged ones.

options.text: Wound healing only involves the growth of existing cells, not the production of new cells through division
options.explanation: Wound healing involves both cell growth and the production of new cells through cell division.

toLevel4.question: A student argues that because red blood cells lose their nucleus, they are no longer considered cells. Apply cell theory to evaluate this argument.

options.text: They are still cells because they originated from pre-existing cells through cell division, even though they are highly specialised
options.explanation: Mature red blood cells arise from pre-existing cells through division and differentiation. While they lose their nucleus, they still originated as cells and retain a plasma membrane and cytoplasm.

options.text: The student is correct because cells must always have a nucleus to be classified as cells by cell theory
options.explanation: Cell theory does not require a nucleus for something to be a cell. Prokaryotic cells also lack a membrane-bound nucleus but are still cells.

options.text: Red blood cells were never cells to begin with and are classified as non-living structures at all stages
options.explanation: Red blood cells develop from nucleated precursor cells through cell division and are classified as cells throughout their existence.

options.text: Cell theory does not apply to blood cells because they exist in a liquid environment rather than solid tissue
options.explanation: Cell theory applies to all cells regardless of their environment. Blood cells are still cells.

toLevel4.question: Apply cell theory to explain why an artificial protein structure built in a laboratory would not be considered living.

options.text: It is not made of cells, was not produced by cell division, and does not meet any principle of cell theory
options.explanation: An artificial protein structure lacks cellular organisation, did not arise from pre-existing cells, and is not a basic unit of life. It fails all three principles of cell theory.

options.text: It would be considered living if it contained the same proteins found in natural living organisms
options.explanation: Containing biological proteins does not make something alive. Cell theory requires cellular structure and origin from pre-existing cells.

options.text: It is living because any structure assembled from biological molecules is classified as alive automatically
options.explanation: Cell theory requires cellular structure, not just biological molecules, for something to be classified as living.

options.text: Cell theory cannot evaluate artificial structures because it only applies to naturally occurring organisms
options.explanation: Cell theory's principles can be applied to any entity to determine whether it meets the criteria for being classified as living.

toLevel4.question: How does cell theory connect to the concept of evolution?

options.text: The principle that all cells arise from pre-existing cells implies that all current life descended from earlier cells through an unbroken lineage
options.explanation: Cell theory's third principle supports evolutionary thinking: every cell today is descended from previous cells, establishing a continuous lineage from the first cells to all current life.

options.text: Cell theory and evolution are completely unrelated concepts with no connection in modern biology
options.explanation: Cell theory's principle of cells arising from pre-existing cells directly supports the evolutionary concept of common descent.

options.text: Cell theory contradicts evolution because it states that cells cannot change over time through any mechanism
options.explanation: Cell theory states cells come from pre-existing cells but does not prevent cells from changing over time through mutations and natural selection.

options.text: Evolution only applies to multicellular organisms, while cell theory only applies to unicellular organisms
options.explanation: Both cell theory and evolution apply to all living organisms, whether unicellular or multicellular.

toLevel4.question: A crystal grows in size and can be broken to form new crystals. Apply cell theory to explain why crystals are not living.

options.text: Crystals are not made of cells and their growth occurs through chemical addition, not cell division
options.explanation: Crystal growth involves adding molecules to a lattice structure, not cell division. Crystals lack cells and do not meet the requirements of cell theory for living things.

options.text: Crystals are living because they grow and can reproduce when broken, meeting two criteria for life
options.explanation: Cell theory requires cellular structure. Crystal growth and fragmentation are physical processes, not biological cell division.

options.text: Cell theory cannot determine whether crystals are living because they are geological, not biological structures
options.explanation: Cell theory can be applied: crystals lack cells and therefore are not living, regardless of their geological nature.

options.text: Crystals are considered living by most biologists because they display organised structure and growth
options.explanation: Organised structure and growth alone do not qualify something as living. Cell theory requires cellular organisation.

toLevel4.question: Prions are not living because they lack {{blank:1}} structure and do not arise from pre-existing {{blank:2}}.
Wound healing demonstrates cell theory because new cells arise from {{blank:1}} cells through {{blank:2}}.
Crystal growth involves adding {{blank:1}} to a lattice, not {{blank:2}} division, so crystals are not living.

toLevel5.question: Evaluate the statement: 'Cell theory is incomplete because it cannot explain the origin of the very first cell.'

options.text: This is a valid observation because the third principle assumes pre-existing cells, but abiogenesis research addresses how the first cell may have arisen
options.explanation: Cell theory's third principle requires pre-existing cells. The origin of the first cell is studied through abiogenesis research. This is a recognised limitation but does not invalidate cell theory for current biology.

options.text: Cell theory is completely wrong because it cannot explain the origin of the first cell on Earth
options.explanation: Cell theory accurately describes how current life works. The origin of the first cell is a separate question that does not invalidate the theory's principles.

options.text: Cell theory fully explains the origin of the first cell through spontaneous generation of living matter
options.explanation: Cell theory rejects spontaneous generation. The origin of the first cell is an open research question addressed by abiogenesis studies.

options.text: The first cell did not need to originate because cells have always existed without any beginning point
options.explanation: The Earth and its conditions for life had a beginning. The origin of the first cell is a legitimate scientific question.

toLevel5.question: Analyse how cell theory would be challenged if scientists discovered a truly self-replicating non-cellular entity.

options.text: It would prompt revision of cell theory's first principle, potentially expanding the definition of life beyond cells
options.explanation: A self-replicating non-cellular entity would challenge the principle that all living things must be made of cells, potentially requiring an expanded definition of life.

options.text: Cell theory would remain completely unchanged because no discoveries can ever challenge established theories
options.explanation: Scientific theories are updated when new evidence challenges them. A self-replicating non-cellular entity would be significant.

options.text: It would be impossible for such an entity to exist because cell theory absolutely prevents it from occurring
options.explanation: Cell theory describes current observations; it does not prevent the existence of entities that might challenge its principles.

options.text: Such a discovery would have no significance for biology because only cells matter in the study of life
options.explanation: The discovery would be highly significant, potentially redefining what constitutes life and requiring revision of cell theory.

toLevel5.question: Compare the application of cell theory to classifying bacteria, viruses, and prions. What pattern emerges?

options.text: Only bacteria are living because they have cells; viruses and prions are progressively simpler non-cellular entities
options.explanation: Bacteria have cells and are living. Viruses have genetic material but lack cells. Prions are just misfolded proteins. Cell theory classifies only the cellular entity (bacteria) as living.

options.text: All three are living because they can all interact with living cells in some way during infection
options.explanation: Interacting with cells does not make something living. Cell theory requires cellular structure for classification as living.

options.text: None of the three are living because they are all too small to be considered organisms under cell theory
options.explanation: Bacteria are living cellular organisms. Size does not determine whether something is alive; cellular structure does.

options.text: Cell theory cannot classify any of these because they were discovered after cell theory was first proposed
options.explanation: Cell theory's principles are timeless and can be applied to any entity, regardless of when it was discovered.

toLevel5.question: Evaluate how cell theory supports the use of cell cultures in medical research.

options.text: Cell theory's principle that cells arise from pre-existing cells means cell lines can be grown indefinitely from original samples through repeated division
options.explanation: Because cells divide to produce new cells, researchers can maintain cell cultures indefinitely, growing new cells from the original sample for testing drugs, studying diseases, and developing treatments.

options.text: Cell theory does not support cell culture research because growing cells outside the body contradicts natural cell behaviour
options.explanation: Cell theory's principle that cells arise from pre-existing cells applies regardless of location. Cell cultures demonstrate this principle in a laboratory setting.

options.text: Cell cultures work because cells arise spontaneously in the growth medium, not from pre-existing cells
options.explanation: Cell cultures grow because existing cells divide to produce new cells, consistent with cell theory. Cells do not arise spontaneously.

options.text: Cell theory has no connection to medical research and is only relevant to theoretical biology studies
options.explanation: Cell theory underpins practical applications including cell culture, tissue engineering, and medical research.

toLevel5.question: Analyse the claim: 'Cell theory is just a theory, so it might not be true.'

options.text: In science, a theory is a well-supported explanation backed by extensive evidence, not a guess. Cell theory is strongly supported by centuries of evidence.
options.explanation: Scientific theories are explanations supported by extensive evidence and testing. Cell theory is one of the most well-supported theories in biology, confirmed by centuries of observation and experimentation.

options.text: This claim is correct because scientific theories are always uncertain and should not be trusted or used
options.explanation: Scientific theories are among the most reliable explanations in science. Calling something a 'theory' in science indicates strong support, not uncertainty.

options.text: This claim is correct because cell theory was proposed so long ago that it must be outdated by now
options.explanation: Cell theory has been continuously confirmed and refined over centuries. Its age does not reduce its validity.

options.text: This claim cannot be evaluated because the word 'theory' has no established meaning in scientific terminology
options.explanation: In science, 'theory' has a specific meaning: a well-supported explanation for observed phenomena, backed by extensive evidence.

toLevel5.question: Compare the implications of cell theory for understanding cancer and normal cell growth.

options.text: Cell theory explains that cancer cells, like normal cells, arise from pre-existing cells, but their division becomes uncontrolled
options.explanation: Cell theory's principle applies to cancer: cancer cells arise from pre-existing normal cells through division, but mutations cause the division to become unregulated and uncontrolled.

options.text: Cancer cells arise spontaneously from non-living matter, contradicting cell theory's third principle entirely
options.explanation: Cancer cells arise from pre-existing cells that have undergone mutations, consistent with cell theory.

options.text: Cell theory does not apply to cancer because cancer is a disease, not a normal biological process
options.explanation: Cell theory applies to all cells, including cancer cells. Understanding that cancer cells arise from normal cells through division is fundamental to cancer biology.

options.text: Cancer and normal cell growth are completely unrelated processes with no connection to cell theory
options.explanation: Both cancer and normal growth involve cell division from pre-existing cells, directly relating to cell theory.

toLevel5.question: Evaluate how advances in synthetic biology, where scientists attempt to create artificial cells, might relate to cell theory.

options.text: Creating artificial cells would test the boundaries of cell theory by producing cells not derived from pre-existing cells through natural division
options.explanation: If scientists create functional artificial cells from non-living components, it would challenge the principle that all cells arise from pre-existing cells, potentially expanding our understanding of cell theory.

options.text: Synthetic biology has no connection to cell theory because artificial structures cannot be related to natural biology
options.explanation: Synthetic biology directly tests cell theory's principles by attempting to create cells from non-cellular components.

options.text: Cell theory would be completely disproven if an artificial cell were ever created in a laboratory setting
options.explanation: Creating an artificial cell might refine cell theory's boundaries but would not completely disprove it, as the theory still describes how natural cells function.

options.text: Artificial cells have already been created and cell theory has been abandoned by all modern biologists worldwide
options.explanation: While progress has been made in synthetic biology, fully artificial living cells have not been created, and cell theory remains a cornerstone of biology.

toLevel5.question: Assess the historical significance of cell theory in replacing the earlier idea of spontaneous generation.

options.text: Cell theory provided evidence-based understanding that life comes from existing life, replacing the unfounded belief that organisms arise from non-living matter
options.explanation: Cell theory, supported by experiments like Pasteur's, replaced spontaneous generation with the evidence-based principle that all cells arise from pre-existing cells.

options.text: Spontaneous generation was actually correct, and cell theory has since been shown to be wrong about this
options.explanation: Extensive evidence supports cell theory's principle that cells arise from pre-existing cells. Spontaneous generation has been conclusively disproven.

options.text: Cell theory and spontaneous generation are equally valid explanations that scientists have not been able to decide between
options.explanation: Spontaneous generation has been conclusively disproven. Cell theory is the accepted, evidence-based explanation.

options.text: Spontaneous generation was never a real belief and was invented to make cell theory seem more important by comparison
options.explanation: Spontaneous generation was a widely held belief for centuries before being disproven by experiments supporting cell theory.

toLevel5.question: Cell theory's third principle has a recognised limitation regarding the origin of the {{blank:1}} cell, which is studied through {{blank:2}} research.
